profile: Nutrition to Overcome Stress from Training Load & Life Load

biological_effects: Increased cortisol leading to muscle breakdown, fat storage, and sleep disruption
Depletion of key nutrients (magnesium, vitamin C, B-vitamins, omega-3)
Oxidative stress and inflammation causing fatigue and impaired recovery
Suppressed immune function raising illness risk
impact_of_stress.principle: Nutrition should lower stress hormones, reduce oxidative damage, stabilize energy, and support brain chemistry.

carbohydrates.role: Blunts cortisol, restores glycogen, stabilizes mood and energy
carbohydrates.post_workout: 1 g/kg with protein to suppress cortisol and enhance recovery

proteins.role: Provides amino acids for recovery and neurotransmitter support (serotonin, dopamine)

fats.role: Supports hormone balance and stress resilience
fats.daily_target: 20–30% of calories with emphasis on omega-3

micronutrients_adaptogens.benefit: Nervous system relaxation, better sleep, reduced cortisol
Supports immunity and recovery under stress
Improves stress tolerance and reduces fatigue

hydration.training: Add electrolytes for prolonged sweating or heat exposure
hydration.importance: Dehydration raises cortisol and impairs mood

recovery_timing.pre_workout: Carbs + protein (e.g., Greek yogurt + oats + berries)
recovery_timing.during_workout: 30–60 g carbs/hour + electrolytes if >90 min intense
recovery_timing.post_workout: Carbs 1 g/kg + protein 0.3 g/kg within 1–2 hours
recovery_timing.evening: Slow-digesting protein (casein/soy/yogurt) + magnesium-rich food + herbal tea (chamomile, lemon balm)

lifestyle_integration.sleep: 7–9 hours supported by tryptophan-rich foods (turkey, oats, dairy)
lifestyle_integration.caffeine: 3–6 mg/kg can enhance training, but avoid 6–8 h before bed
lifestyle_integration.alcohol: Minimize as it worsens stress load and recovery

daily_checklist: Meet carb needs (3–6 g/kg/day) to regulate cortisol
Hit protein target (1.6–2.0 g/kg/day) evenly across meals
Prioritize omega-3 rich foods or supplements
Include fruits/vegetables for antioxidants and micronutrients
Maintain vitamin D and magnesium levels
Consider adaptogens if stress is chronically high
scientific_references: Burke LM et al. (2011). Carbohydrates for training and competition. J Sports Sci.
Phillips SM & Van Loon LJ (2011). Dietary protein for athletes. Appl Physiol Nutr Metab.
Owens DJ et al. (2015). Omega-3 fatty acids and recovery. Eur J Appl Physiol.
Grosso G et al. (2014). Mediterranean diet and depression risk. Nutrients.
Chandrasekhar K et al. (2012). Ashwagandha root extract reduces stress and anxiety. Indian J Psychol Med.
